Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Collaborative Research: Time-dependent coupling of the solar corona and inner heliosphere: Interfacing LFM-helio with MAS
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks funding for the development and validation of a new sophisticated numerical model that would follow Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) from their birth in the solar corona, through interactions with the ambient solar wind, and out to 1 AU. The finished model will combine two established, well-recognized codes, "MAS" (MHD Around a Sphere) to model the solar corona out to about 30 solar radii and "LFM Helio," an adaptation of the LFM code originally developed for magnetospheric simulations, that would follow the propagation out to 1 AU. Specific tasks to be completed include: 1) Steady-state MAS/LFM-helio coupling to obtain the ambient solar wind configuration throughout the corona and inner heliosphere prior to CME initiation; 2) Time-dependent coupling allowing seamless propagation of the CME structure through the interface between the coronal and inner heliosphere domains located at ∼ 30 RE; 3) Vetting of the resultant coupled model by performing corona-inner heliosphere simulations, investigations of CME interaction with the ambient solar wind and each other, and comparisons with heliospheric imaging.

If a major CME was to hit the earth it could have major consequences on everything from GPS satellites to the terrestrial power grid. Hence, understanding how CMEs propagate from the Sun to the Earth is perhaps the most important aspect of space weather forecasting. A female PhD student would be trained under this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how the Sun affects the Earth's environment has become an important issue for societyin general. This Space Weather has the capability of affecting satellites used for communication andGPS, for example, as well as power grids on the ground. In this project we have made a step towardimproving the modeling of the plasma and magnetic wind streaming from the Sun, the solar wind. Thephysics of the upper solar atmosphere, the corona, is much more complicated than its extension, thefree-streaming solar wind. Different phyical models are therefore used for the two regions. In thisproject we have developed a means for coupling the models for the two different regions together toprovide a single simulation model to go from the solar surface to the Earth. In addition we haveshown the importance of the numerical methods used to calculate the propagation of the undisturbedsolar wind and eruptive phenomena from the Sun.
The figure shows a simulation coming out of this project of one such an eruption, known as a coronalmass ejection (CME). A CME that hits the Earth can cause geomagnetic storms. The most visible effectis that of enhanced aurora, but more important effects can cause damage both to space borne andground infrastructure. The top panel of the figure shows the undisturbed solar wind. The coloredplane shows the velocity of the solar wind almost entirely radial outward from the Sun at hundredsof kilometers per second. The structure in the solar wind speed is due to the structure in thecorona reflected in the the outflow velocity. Field lines originating from the Sun where the CMEwill erupt are also shown. Because of the Sun's rotation the field lines are twisted into a spiralpattern, known as the Parker spiral. In the second panel, the CME has erupted. Note that the regionof disturbed field lines corresponds to much higher velocity (the light color). The final panelshows the development at a later time when the CME is partway to the Earth. Even though the CME waslaunched from a single area on the Sun, the effects in the solar wind can be seen all the way to theother side of the Sun. 
This project has been a step in improving the modeling of phenomena originating on the Sun movingout into the solar wind and affecting the Earth and our technological infrastructure. The ultimategoal of such work is to bring the footing of Space Weather modeling up to that of atmosphericweather. That goal is still quite far away, but the results of this project will help to get to that goal.
